artifact_name: model(sword or dagger and sheath); figure
Description: Egyptian terracotta model of dagger, or sword with separate sheath. A mould-made model sword and its scabbard, with a ribbed handle and quadruple-balled pommel, the guard of pedimental form enclosing a raised stud. The blade has been pared. The separate scabbard has reinforced edgings, each terminating in a loop at the bottom and plain horizontal mouldings, probably representing metal bindings; there is a loop for suspension on each side near the top. The backs of both the sword and the scabbard are plain; both were made in two-piece moulds. Brown Nile silt with a reddish core and abundant fine gold mica and white inclusions (<1.5mm).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), Site 95 (Petrie), the terracotta workshop, at the eastern edge of the town
Curator's comments: Locally made at Site 95, terracotta workshop at the eastern edge of the city. BM1886,0401.1444, 1886,0401.1451-2, 1886,0401.1537-40, 1886,0401.1574 and 1888,0601.108 were found together at this terracottas workshop (Petrie 1886: 45). Petrie dates this workshop to about the end of the 1st century AD, Bailey 3rd to 2nd century BC. A similar sword was dated to the Roman period (Schmidt 1997: no. 184). Sekunda (1995: fig. 126) remarks on its four-part pommel and states that it is derived from a Galatian sword. Parallel found in the Fayum, now in Cairo Museum (TR6/3/36/1=SR5/1134). 'Site 9[5]' written on the object in pencil. Site 95 is the terracotta workshop, found by sebakhin in 1885, at the eastern edge of the city. Schmidt, S. 1997. 'Katalog der ptolemäischen und kaiserzeitlichen Objekte aus Ägypten im Akademischen Kunstmuseum Bonn.’ Munich. Sekunda, N. 1995. ‘Seleucid and Ptolemaic Reformed Armies 168-145 BC, vol. II: The Ptolemaic Army.’ Stockport.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C629)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DF.04) (Phase 1)
